Euroclear, the Belgian institution managing frozen Russian assets that will 'not rule out' suing the EU
Subhead: Euroclear, a little-known but central player in Europe's financial system, holds €193 billion in frozen Russian assets that, since the invasion of Ukraine, have drawn intense scrutiny. Its director general, Valérie Urbain, warns that confiscation – illegal under international law – would weaken Europe's position.

Subhead: The gradual shift in political discourse, along with measures taken in the name of fighting terrorism and separatism, has convinced many in the practicing Muslim community that it is being collectively targeted.

Title: Maduro denounces US–Trinidad drills as 'irresponsible' and urges mobilization
Subhead: The Venezuelan president has accused Washington of using expanded military deployments in the Caribbean as cover for efforts to destabilize his government.

Title: 'The Beast in Me' on Netflix: The neighbor with a troubled past
Subhead: Claire Danes and Matthew Rhys rescue 'The Beast in Me' from banality, even if the literary thriller miniseries is rather thin.

Title: At Paris Photo, posthumous prints come back to life
Subhead: Long dismissed by collectors and institutions, prints made after a photographer's death – whether with or without the artist's explicit consent – have multiplied at the fair, attracting a new audience drawn by lower prices.

COP30: 'Those drawn to China's environmental push should keep a few facts in mind'
Subhead: China is presenting itself as the leader in the renewable energy economy, positioning itself against the United States, which remains entrenched in fossil fuels. Yet, this transition has proven misleading, writes Pascal Riché in his column for Le Monde.

Title: 'Delhi is no longer livable': Deadly pollution in Indian capital claims more than 17,000 lives each year
Subhead: Millions of firecrackers set off during the Hindu festival of Diwali at the end of October have worsened the already extreme fine particle pollution engulfing the megacity. Every winter, Delhi's 30 million residents face a toxic nightmare, while blistering heat waves strike the city each summer.

Title: Leaders of international Gen Z movement reflect on their countries' political futures
Subhead: From Nepal to Madagascar and Peru, youth-led revolts driven by socio-economic demands have shaken governments. But their horizontal mobilization strategy, born of digital culture, now hampers the political outcomes of these movements.
